<snip>
Comparison with WWW is not fair.  There is a single shared semantic
=
for human readable web pages, and our brains (so far) are way better
resolv=
ing the semantics, compared to software code.
</snip>

think about what you=
 say here: that there is a "shared semantic"
understanding. and where does =
this understanding exist? only (and
solely) in the head of humans?

after c=
areful review, i claim you will find that there *are*
real-world markers, i=
ndicators, semantic "switches" that exist in the
real world; ones that are =
recognized, parsed, and (when appropriate)
activated by humans. Currently, =
thesemarkers are the visual cues that
are rendered by common Web browsers v=
ia the messages sent by servers
in the most ubiquitous human-centered hyper=
media format of the day;
HTML.

"Semantic meaning" is an emergent property.=
 In the case of HTML that
property is "created" by humans when they observe=
 the visual
"landscape" rendered by  Web browsers.

Does anyone here want t=
o assert that this "semantic meaning" can
_only_ emerge when humans are *di=
rectly* involved in the real-time
interpretation of messages that contain t=
hese (or similar) markers? Or
is it possible that humans can "code" agents =
to have (at least some
of) this same ability to recognize, parse, and activ=
ate the
"affordances" found in the hypermedia landscape?

It is my assertio=
n that the latter is the case. I also contend that
making the assumption th=
at this is possible is a key step in advancing
the art and theory of distri=
buted hypermedia.

mca
http://amundsen.com/blog/
http://twitter.com@mamund
=
http://mamund.com/foaf.rdf#me




On Tue, Jan 3, 2012 at 09:28, Nina Jeliaz=
kova <jeliazkova.nina@...> wrote:
> Hello,
>
> On 3 January 2012 15:5=
2, Alexander Johannesen
> <alexander.johannesen@...> wrote:
>> Hiya,
=
>>
>>> "this isn't a REST problem".
>>
>> "Nina Jeliazkova" <jeliazkova.nin=
a@...> wrote:
>>> Well, it should be, otherwise a distributed archite=
cture is largely
>>> useless.
>>
>> Hmm. Sounds like you underestimate the =
usefulness of the massively
>> distributed architecture called Internet. :)=

>
> Internet became massively useful after 1) distributed name resolution
=
> called DNS was invented and 2) search engines became powerful enough.
>
>=
>
>>> Unless we are assuming any REST system is an isolated server
>>> or s=
erver farm, running under single authority, and all potential
>>> users and=
 clients are aware of it and love to read its documentation.
>>
>> The ambi=
guity of REST/HTTP is exactly why it *is* so powerful as a concept.
>
> AFA=
IK , REST is not defined as HTTP specific, on the contrary.
>
>> Yes, you h=
ave to work a little harder on the application semantics and the
>> glue of=
 the ontology layer, but it comes with the amazing bonus of all the
>> good=
ness of WWW. Surely, we can't ignore its success? It's the ease of
>> worki=
ng with it, of setting it up, and the ambigous nature of each request
>> (t=
hat can be tunneled through anything) and the constraints on them (for
>> c=
acheability, etc.) that makes that possible.
>>
>
> I don't challenge the u=
sefulness of catch-all POST on network level,
> on the contrary.
>
> What I=
 do challenge is the missing semantic level, which makes
> impossible to fi=
nd out what all these resources are about. I don't
> understand what's wron=
g of admitting HTTP is _the_ transport level for
> myriad of specific appli=
cations, defining their own semantics in the
> HTTP message body payload. =
=A0Or do we perceive OSI architecture fixed
> in stone once and forever? =
=A0Sure it is in the textbooks, but not
> always as positive example. It is=
 often cited that early in the
> Internet history, there were no precise id=
ea what the applications
> will appear, so why we insist there could be no =
layer above OSI 7?
>
> Comparison with WWW is not fair. =A0There is a singl=
e shared semantic
> for human readable web pages, and our brains (so far) a=
re way better
> resolving the semantics, compared to software code.
>
>>> F=
inding resources is critical part of any network architecture. If I
>>> do =
not know nothing of Amazon, and there is no any search engine
>>> available=
, =A0how I am supposed to find where to buy online books? Even
>>> how I am=
 supposed to know I _could_ buy books online?
>>
>> But why are you raising=
 these what-if questions? Do you have some scenarios
>> that you are concre=
tely struggeling with, or are good examples of HTTP gone
>> bad? I fear I d=
o not understand "what if there are no search engines",
>> because there ar=
e.
>>
>
> Well, having used Internet before =A0Altavista, Google, et al. be=
came
> into their force, I do remember times when web sites were
> particip=
ating in "rings", where each site was happy to include links
> to the next =
one in the ring, thus allowing a new sites to become
> visible. =A0Another =
way to learn about a web site was for somebody to
> share the link by email=
, or even offline. =A0The HATEOAS "follow your
> nose" approach reminds me =
exactly this - no global knowledge, just
> follow the next step. The power =
of Internet rose when the web of links
> started to be analysed as a whole,=
 not just looking at the next peek.
>
> However, web services (not only RES=
T) are in the pre-search era, quite
> possible due to common semantics lack=
ing. =A0May be because of something
> else as well. IMHO only of course.
>
=
> Scenarios - well, couple of, but details are not necessary in the
> scope=
 of this thread. Basically, having number of REST services under
> common A=
PI running in several places in the world, how do you find if
> there is a =
specific piece of information that could be retrieved from
> any of them, o=
r specific processing capability available? =A0Sure there
> are custom solu=
tions, but from this discussion I gather a generic one
> is hardly of inter=
est.
>
>>> Well, we do roughly the same, each resource describing itself wi=
th
>>> RDF, according to a specific ontology. But I would not say this is t=
he
>>> mainstream approach.
>>
>> Depends on where you dip your toe. But ev=
en if that was true, does that make
>> it wrong?
>
> Of course not.

ards,
